articles.title: Scientists make 'superfood' that could save honeybees
articles.summary: We rely on honeybees to pollinate our crops and a new food could protect them from growing threats.
articles.content:
Scientists make 'superfood' that could save honeybees

13 hours ago Share Save Georgina Rannard Climate and science correspondent Share Save

Gwyndaf Hughes/BBC

Scientists have developed a honeybee "superfood" that could protect the animals against the threats of climate change and habitat loss. Bee colonies that ate the supplement during trials had up to 15 times more baby bees that grew to adulthood. Honeybees are a vital part of food production and contribute to pollinating 70% of leading global crops. "This technological breakthrough provides all the nutrients bees need to survive, meaning we can continue to feed them even when there's not enough pollen," senior author Professor Geraldine Wright at the University of Oxford told BBC News. "It really is a huge accomplishment," she says.

Gywndaf Hughes/BBC

Honeybees globally are facing severe declines, due to nutrient deficiencies, viral diseases, climate change and other factors. In the US, annual colony losses have ranged between 40-50% in the last decade and are expected to increase. Beekeepers in the UK have faced serious challenges too. Nick Mensikov, chair of the Cardiff, Vale and Valleys Beekeepers Association, told BBC News that he lost 75% of his colonies last winter and that this has been seen across South Wales. "Although the hives have all been full of food, the bees have just dwindled. Most of the bees survived through January, February, and then they just vanished," he says.

Gwyndaf Hughes/BBC Nick Mensikov has kept hives for 15 years and sells honey in South Wales

Honeybees feed on pollen and nectar from flowers that contain the nutrients, including lipids called sterols that are necessary for their development. They make honey in hives, which becomes their food source over winter when flowers have stopped producing pollen. When beekeepers take out honey to sell, or, increasingly, when there isn't enough pollen available, they give the insects supplementary food. But that food is made up of protein flour, sugar and water, and has always lacked the nutrients bees require. It is like humans eating a diet without carbohydrates, amino acids, or other vital nutrients. Sterol has always proved very difficult to manufacture, but Prof Wright has led a group of scientists for 15 years to identify which exact sterols bees need and how to engineer them.

Gwyndaf Hughes/BBC Professor Geraldine Wright was inspired to work on bee nutrition after beekeepers told her about how many of their bees were dying

In the lab at Oxford, PhD student Jennifer Chennells showed us small clear boxes of honeybees in an incubator that she feeds with different foods she has made. She uses kitchen equipment you could find at home to make the raw ingredients, and rolls out glossy, white tubes of food. "We put ingredients into what's like a cookie dough, with different proteins, fats, different amounts of carbohydrate, and the micronutrients that bees need. It's to try to work out what they like best and what's best for them," she says. She pushes the tubes inside the boxes and bees nibble at the mixture. It's in this lab that, using gene editing, Prof Wright's team successfully made a yeast that can produce the six sterols that bees need. "It's a huge breakthrough. When my student was able to engineer the yeast to create the sterols, she sent me a picture of the chromatogram that was a result of the work," she says, referring to a chart of the substance structure. "I still have it on the wall of my office," she explains.

See inside the hive that tested honeybee 'superfood'

The "superfood" was fed to bees in the lab's hives for three months. The results showed that colonies fed the food had up to 15 times more baby bees that made it to adulthood. "When the bees have a complete nutrition they should be healthier and less susceptible to disease," Prof Wright says. Prof Wright says the food would be particularly useful during summers like this one when flowering plants appear to have stopped producing early.

Gwyndaf Hughes/BBC Beekeepers often feed supplementary food to bees to sustain them
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in developing a nutrient-complete 'superfood' for honeybees, which are vital pollinators for 70% of global crops. This innovation addresses serious threats to bee populations caused by climate change, habitat loss, and nutrient deficiencies, with demonstrated large-scale positive impact on bee colony survival and reproduction. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a meaningful advancement with broad environmental and agricultural implications.
articles.personality_title: Scientists create nutrient-rich superfood to help honeybees thrive
articles.personality_presentation:

However, their numbers are dropping because of problems like climate change, diseases, and lack of good food. **What happened** – Researchers at the University of Oxford developed a special “superfood” for honeybees. This new food includes important nutrients called sterols, which are hard to produce but vital for bees’ growth. Scientists used gene editing to create yeast that makes these sterols. When bees ate this superfood in tests, their colonies produced up to 15 times more baby bees that grew into adults.

**Impact** – This is important because it helps bees survive and stay healthy, especially when flowers don’t provide enough pollen. Beekeepers who have lost many colonies due to poor nutrition and harsh conditions may find this superfood helpful in protecting their hives.

**What’s next step** – Scientists will likely work on producing this superfood on a larger scale and testing it with more bee colonies in different places. If successful, it could become a common way to support bees worldwide, especially during tough seasons when flowers provide less food.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new nutrient-rich superfood developed by scientists could help honeybees survive and grow stronger, supporting the crops they pollinate worldwide.

articles.title: Saving China's finless porpoise from the brink of extinction
articles.summary: Scientists are racing to protect what some view as "the most important animal" in the Yangtze.
articles.content:
Saving China's finless porpoise from the brink of extinction

6 hours ago Share Save Stephen McDonell China correspondent Share Save

Watch: Endangered porpoises at the Institute of Hydrobiology in Wuhan, China

Chinese scientists are in a battle to save one of the last large animal species living in the Yangtze River – and a complete ban on fishing in the region is helping them. At the Institute of Hydrobiology in Wuhan, just 5km (3.1 miles) from the banks of the river, the preserved bodies of the now-extinct river dolphin (baiji in Chinese) and paddle fish sit silently behind panes of glass. "Now that those have become extinct, we're going to save the Yangtze river porpoise," Professor Wang Xi tells the BBC. "It has become the most important animal here." It was in 2002 that the last known baiji died, 22 years after researchers at the Institute started caring for it. A year later, the last known paddle fish - a type of ray-finned fish which can grow to more than 3 metres - was accidentally caught by fishermen and, despite being radio tagged and released, disappeared. The goal now is to stop the Yangtze finless river porpoise - 1,200 of which remain in the wild, according to current estimates – from suffering the same fate. "It's the only top-level predator left in the river," Professor Wang explains. "They are rare and their numbers reflect the health of the entire system's ecology."

The last river dolphin, or baiji, died in 2002 - the only examples remaining are in museums

The idea of a halt on all fishing was first conceived by Professor Cao Wenxuan from the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) in 2006, but it took a lot more pressure from fellow scientists before a full 10-year-ban finally came into force nearly five years ago. Enforced by police, the ban carries potential prison time for those caught fishing right along the Yangtze, as well as adjacent lakes and tributaries. It's been hugely disruptive, and put 220,000 fishermen out of work. Yet the finless porpoise, which belongs to the oldest living branch of the porpoise family tree, remains critically endangered today. Those the BBC was shown at the Institute are being held in captivity to be studied by CAS. They can be seen from above the water or below, after taking the stairs down beside a deep tank where the observation area is located. The scientists say they get excited in the company of humans, and they certainly appear to be showing off: racing through the water and swimming at speed, close to the glass with people on the other side. Swimming past, they seem to look at you with a mischievous smile. In the wild, they are still hanging on where other species could not. The construction of the main part of Three Gorges Dam in 2006 didn't directly impact the finless porpoise, which don't have to go upstream to spawn, although it did affect the fish they eat.

Yang He The finless porpoise belongs to the oldest living branch of the porpoise family tree

For other large marine animals, like the paddle fish or the Chinese sturgeon, the structure was catastrophic. Wang Ding, a member of the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), who specialises in cetaceans like the finless porpoise, has dedicated his life to preserving the health of the Yangtze. He can see the good and the bad with these dams – and recalls how things used to be. "Every flood season we'd have to organise a team with strong muscles, using many men, to go to sleep on the bank of the river, just in case a flood came," he says. "Then, if the flood hit, everyone would do their best to try to keep the levy banks solid, to make sure they were not broken by the dangerous rushing water." Now, he says, the Three Gorges Dam mitigates against the flooding. As Professor Wang points out, however, this massive, river-blocking structure also prevents the Yangtze's giant sturgeons from reaching their spawning grounds. While the endangered fish had briefly seemed to find an alternative location, he says, this is no longer the case - and these days sturgeons are only in the river because researchers are pouring them in, 10,000 at a time.

The giant Three Gorges Dam has affected local wildlife along the river

Despite over a million captive-bred sturgeon being released into the Yangtze last year, attempts to boost the population have been unsuccessful, as the fish are not reproducing by themselves in the wild. So the finless porpoise doesn't end up like this, Professor Wang and other scientists are hoping that the current complete fishing ban will continue after the initial 10 years is up. Their research, published in the Bulletin of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, records a drastic increase in fish numbers since the ban came into effect in 2021. Another threat to the finless porpoise, however, might be harder to resolve. Wang Xi pointed out that "ships are very dangerous for animal's brains because they are very noisy". This is said to produce a form of underwater noise pollution which distresses the animals. Chinese scientists think that the sound from ships may have contributed to the demise of the Yangtze's baiji river dolphins, which used sonar to communicate. But it's one thing to ban fishing - it would be quite another to completely stop the busy river traffic which delivers passengers as well as goods, and provides lifeblood for much of central China's economy. More achievable was forcing factories which produce chemicals to move away from the Yangtze. Thousands of these have been shut down or relocated over the past decade, in a move that is said to have significantly improved the river's water quality. There has also been community involvement in the porpoise preservation push.

Yang He Porpoise numbers are now rising again thanks to conservation efforts
articles.reasoning: The article describes significant conservation efforts to save the critically endangered Yangtze finless porpoise, including a complete fishing ban, improved water quality, and scientific research. These actions have led to a measurable increase in fish populations and offer hope for the species' survival, representing a meaningful environmental success with broad ecological and societal impact.
articles.personality_title: China’s fishing ban helps save rare Yangtze finless porpoise
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Yangtze River in China is home to unique animals like the finless porpoise, but many species, including the river dolphin and paddle fish, have already disappeared. Scientists worry the finless porpoise might be next.

**What happened** – To protect the finless porpoise, Chinese scientists and officials introduced a complete ban on fishing in the Yangtze and its connected lakes and rivers about five years ago. This ban, enforced by police, stopped fishing activities that threatened the porpoise’s food and habitat. At the same time, factories that polluted the river were moved or closed, improving water quality.

**Impact** – Since the fishing ban started in 2021, fish numbers in the river have grown a lot, which means more food for the porpoises. The finless porpoise is now showing signs of recovery, and scientists hope this will stop it from becoming extinct like other Yangtze animals. However, noise from ships still poses a challenge, as it disturbs the animals and affects their communication.

**What’s next step** – Scientists want the fishing ban to continue beyond the first 10 years to keep helping the porpoise. They are also studying how to reduce noise pollution in the river. Meanwhile, community support and ongoing research will play important roles in protecting the finless porpoise and the river’s health.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A strict fishing ban and cleaner water have helped the endangered Yangtze finless porpoise survive, showing how strong actions can protect rare river animals.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'interdiction de la pêche en Chine aide à sauver le marsouin sans nageoires du Yangtsé
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le fleuve Yangtsé en Chine abrite des animaux uniques comme le marsouin sans nageoires, mais beaucoup d’espèces, dont le dauphin du fleuve et l’esturgeon, ont déjà disparu. Les scientifiques craignent que le marsouin ne soit le prochain.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Pour protéger le marsouin sans nageoires, des scientifiques et responsables chinois ont instauré il y a environ cinq ans une interdiction totale de la pêche dans le Yangtsé et ses lacs et rivières voisins. Cette interdiction, appliquée par la police, a stoppé les activités de pêche qui menaçaient la nourriture et l’habitat du marsouin. En même temps, des usines polluantes ont été déplacées ou fermées, améliorant la qualité de l’eau.

**Impact** – Depuis le début de l’interdiction en 2021, le nombre de poissons dans le fleuve a beaucoup augmenté, ce qui signifie plus de nourriture pour les marsouins. Le marsouin sans nageoires montre maintenant des signes de reprise, et les scientifiques espèrent que cela empêchera son extinction comme d'autres animaux du Yangtsé. Cependant, le bruit des bateaux reste un problème, car il perturbe les animaux et leur communication.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques veulent que l’interdiction de la pêche continue au-delà des dix premières années pour continuer à aider le marsouin. Ils étudient aussi comment réduire la pollution sonore dans le fleuve. En attendant, le soutien des communautés et la recherche continueront de jouer un rôle important pour protéger le marsouin et la santé du fleuve.

**Phrase clé** – Une interdiction stricte de la pêche et une eau plus propre ont aidé le marsouin sans nageoires du Yangtsé à survivre, montrant comment des actions fortes peuvent protéger des animaux rares des rivières.
articles.personality_title_es: La prohibición de pesca en China ayuda a salvar al marsopa sin aletas del Yangtsé
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El río Yangtsé en China es hogar de animales únicos como la marsopa sin aletas, pero muchas especies, incluyendo el delfín de río y el esturión, ya han desaparecido. Los científicos temen que la marsopa sea la próxima.

**Qué pasó** – Para proteger a la marsopa sin aletas, científicos y autoridades chinas impusieron hace unos cinco años una prohibición total de la pesca en el Yangtsé y sus lagos y ríos conectados. Esta prohibición, aplicada por la policía, detuvo las actividades de pesca que amenazaban la comida y el hábitat de la marsopa. Al mismo tiempo, fábricas que contaminaban el río fueron cerradas o trasladadas, mejorando la calidad del agua.

**Impacto** – Desde que comenzó la prohibición en 2021, el número de peces en el río ha aumentado mucho, lo que significa más alimento para las marsopas. La marsopa sin aletas muestra señales de recuperación, y los científicos esperan que esto evite que se extinga como otras especies del Yangtsé. Sin embargo, el ruido de los barcos sigue siendo un problema, ya que molesta a los animales y afecta su comunicación.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos quieren que la prohibición de pesca continúe más allá de los primeros 10 años para seguir ayudando a la marsopa. También estudian cómo reducir la contaminación acústica en el río. Mientras tanto, el apoyo de la comunidad y la investigación continua serán clave para proteger a la marsopa y la salud del río.

**Frase clave** – Una prohibición estricta de la pesca y un agua más limpia han ayudado a la marsopa sin aletas del Yangtsé a sobrevivir, mostrando cómo acciones firmes pueden proteger animales raros de los ríos.

articles.title: Protected seas help kelp forests bounce back from heatwaves
articles.summary: Kelp forests bounce back faster from marine heatwaves when shielded inside Marine Protected Areas. UCLA researchers found that fishing restrictions and predator protection strengthen ecosystem resilience, though results vary by location.
articles.content:
New research finds that Marine Protected Areas can boost the recovery of globally important kelp forests following marine heatwaves. The findings are published in the British Ecological Society's Journal of Applied Ecology.

Using four decades of satellite images, University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) researchers have looked at impacts Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) are having on kelp forests along the coast of California.

They found that although the overall effect of MPAs on kelp forest cover was modest, the benefits became clear in the aftermath of marine heatwaves in 2014-2016, when kelp forests within MPAs were able recover more quickly, particularly in southern California.

"We found that kelp forests inside MPAs showed better recovery after a major climate disturbance compared to similar unprotected areas." Explained Emelly Ortiz-Villa, lead author of the study and a PhD researcher at UCLA Department of Geography.

"Places where fishing is restricted and important predators like lobsters and sheephead are protected saw stronger kelp regrowth. This suggests that MPAs can support ecosystem resilience to climate events like marine heatwaves."

Professor Rick Stafford, Chair of the British Ecological Society Policy Committee, who was not involved in the study said: "It's great to see these results and they clearly show that local action to protect biodiversity and ecosystem function can help prevent changes caused by global pressures such as climate change.

"However, it also demonstrates the need for effective MPAs. In this study, all the MPAs examined regulated fishing activity, and this is not the case for many sites which are designated as MPAs worldwide - including many in the UK."

Kelp forests: a globally important and threatened ecosystem

Kelp forests our found around coastlines all over the world, particularly in cool, temperate waters such as the pacific coast of North America, The UK, South Africa, and Australia.

These complex ecosystems are havens for marine wildlife, including commercially important fish, and are one of the most productive habitats on Earth. They're also efficient in capturing carbon and protect coastlines by buffering against wave energy.

However, kelp forests across the west coast of North America have declined in recent years due to pressures such as marine heatwaves, made more frequent and intense with climate change, and predation from increasing numbers of sea urchins, which have benefitted from population collapses of sea stars, which predate them.

Kyle Cavanaugh, a senior author of the study and professor in the UCLA Department of Geography and Institute of the Environment and Sustainability said: "Kelp forests are facing many threats, including ocean warming, overgrazing, and pollution. These forests can be remarkably resilient to individual stressors, but multi-stressor situations can overwhelm their capacity to recover. By mitigating certain stressors, MPAs can help enhance the resilience of kelp."

Marine protected areas as a conservation tool

MPAs are designated areas of the ocean where human activity is limited to support ecosystems and the species living there. However, protections vary widely and while some areas are no-take zones, others have few restrictions or lack comprehensive management and enforcement. Many even allow destructive practices like bottom trawling.

Effective MPAs form a key part of the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework, agreed at COP15 in 2022, which commits nations to protecting at least 30% of oceans and land by 2030.

"Our findings can inform decisions about where to establish new MPAs or implement other spatial protection measures." said Kyle Cavanaugh. "MPAs will be most effective when located in areas that are inherently more resilient to ocean warming, such as regions with localized upwelling or kelp populations with higher thermal tolerance."

Emelly Villa added: "Our findings suggest that kelp forests could be a useful indicator for tracking the ecological health and climate resilience of protected areas and should be included in long-term monitoring strategies."

Measuring the impact of marine protected areas

To understand the effects MPAs were having on kelp, the researchers used of satellite data from 1984-2022 to compare kelp forests inside and outside of 54 MPAs along the California coast.

By matching each MPA with a reference site with similar environmental conditions, they were able to test whether MPAs helped kelp forests resist loss or recover from extreme marine heatwaves which took place in the North pacific between 2014 and 2016.

The researchers warn that while their findings show that MPAs can help kelp recovery after marine heatwaves, the effect was highly variable depending on location.

"On average, kelp within MPAs showed greater recovery than in the reference sites. However, not all MPAs outperformed their corresponding reference sites, suggesting that additional factors are also play a role in determining resilience." said Kyle Cavanaugh.

The researchers say that future work could look to identify these factors to better understand where and when MPAs are most effective at enhancing kelp resilience.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific finding that Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) enhance the resilience and recovery of kelp forests after marine heatwaves, a major climate-related threat. This has broad environmental implications for biodiversity conservation, climate mitigation, and coastal protection globally. The study is detailed, based on long-term data, and highlights actionable conservation strategies aligned with international biodiversity goals.
articles.personality_title: Protected marine areas help kelp forests recover faster after heatwaves
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Kelp forests are important underwater habitats found along many coastlines, including California. They provide homes for sea creatures, protect coastlines, and help capture carbon. But in recent years, these forests have been damaged by marine heatwaves and other threats.

**What happened** – Researchers from UCLA studied satellite images from 1984 to 2022 to see how kelp forests inside Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) fared compared to those outside. MPAs are ocean zones where fishing and other activities are limited. The study found that kelp forests inside MPAs recovered faster after the marine heatwaves between 2014 and 2016, especially in southern California.

**Impact** – This shows that protecting certain ocean areas from fishing and preserving predators like lobsters helps kelp forests bounce back after climate events. It means MPAs can make these ecosystems stronger and more able to handle changes caused by warming oceans. However, the results varied by location, so not all MPAs had the same effect.

**What's next step** – Scientists want to find out why some MPAs work better than others and how to choose the best spots for protection. This research can guide future plans to create or improve MPAs, helping kelp forests survive as the climate changes.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Marine Protected Areas help kelp forests recover faster from heatwaves by limiting fishing and protecting key species, making these ecosystems more resilient to climate change.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les zones marines protégées aident les forêts de varech à se rétablir plus rapidement après les vagues de chaleur
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les forêts de varech sont des habitats sous-marins importants que l'on trouve le long de nombreuses côtes, notamment en Californie. Elles abritent de nombreuses espèces marines, protègent les côtes et capturent le carbone. Mais ces dernières années, elles ont été endommagées par des vagues de chaleur marine et d'autres menaces.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs de l'UCLA ont étudié des images satellites de 1984 à 2022 pour voir comment les forêts de varech à l'intérieur des zones marines protégées (ZMP) se comportaient par rapport à celles à l'extérieur. Les ZMP sont des zones océaniques où la pêche et certaines activités sont limitées. L'étude montre que les forêts de varech dans ces zones se rétablissaient plus vite après les vagues de chaleur entre 2014 et 2016, surtout en Californie du Sud.

**Impact** – Cela prouve que protéger certaines zones marines de la pêche et préserver des prédateurs comme les homards aide les forêts de varech à mieux se remettre des événements climatiques. Cela signifie que les ZMP renforcent ces écosystèmes face au réchauffement des océans. Toutefois, les résultats varient selon les endroits.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques veulent comprendre pourquoi certaines ZMP fonctionnent mieux que d'autres et comment choisir les meilleurs endroits à protéger. Cette recherche peut guider la création ou l'amélioration des ZMP pour aider les forêts de varech à survivre au changement climatique.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les zones marines protégées favorisent la récupération plus rapide des forêts de varech après les vagues de chaleur en limitant la pêche et en protégeant les espèces clés, rendant ces écosystèmes plus résistants au changement climatique.
articles.personality_title_es: Las áreas marinas protegidas ayudan a que los bosques de kelp se recuperen más rápido tras las olas de calor
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los bosques de kelp son hábitats submarinos importantes que se encuentran en muchas costas, incluyendo California. Son el hogar de muchas especies marinas, protegen las costas y capturan carbono. Pero en años recientes, han sido dañados por olas de calor marinas y otras amenazas.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de UCLA analizaron imágenes satelitales desde 1984 hasta 2022 para ver cómo se recuperaban los bosques de kelp dentro de Áreas Marinas Protegidas (AMP), donde se limita la pesca y otras actividades, en comparación con los que están fuera. Descubrieron que los kelps dentro de las AMP se recuperaron más rápido después de las olas de calor entre 2014 y 2016, especialmente en el sur de California.

**Impacto** – Esto muestra que proteger ciertas áreas del océano de la pesca y cuidar a depredadores importantes como las langostas ayuda a que los bosques de kelp se recuperen mejor tras eventos climáticos. Significa que las AMP hacen estos ecosistemas más fuertes frente al calentamiento del océano. Sin embargo, los resultados varían según la ubicación.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos buscan entender por qué algunas AMP funcionan mejor que otras y cómo elegir los mejores lugares para proteger. Esta investigación puede ayudar a crear o mejorar AMP para que los bosques de kelp sobrevivan al cambio climático.

**Resumen en una frase** – Las Áreas Marinas Protegidas ayudan a que los bosques de kelp se recuperen más rápido de las olas de calor al limitar la pesca y proteger especies clave, haciendo estos ecosistemas más resistentes al cambio climático.

articles.title: Super-cool cement could stop buildings trapping heat inside
articles.summary: A new formulation of cement reflects and emits heat more effectively than normal Portland cement, so it stays much cooler on a hot day
articles.content:
A new formulation of cement reflects and emits heat more effectively than normal Portland cement, so it stays much cooler on a hot day

Concrete buildings absorb heat in hot weather Panther Media Global/Alamy

Cement that can cool itself by reflecting light on the outside and releasing heat from its surface could help buildings stay comfortable without needing air conditioning.

Normal cement tends to absorb infrared radiation from the sun and store it as heat, which can increase the temperature inside cement buildings as well as that of the surrounding air.

Advertisement

So Fengyin Du at Purdue University in Indiana and her colleagues decided to address this by creating a cement in which tiny reflective crystals of a mineral called ettringite collect on the surface.

The team’s cement emits infrared light from its surface, rather than storing it, and so loses heat quickly. “It works like a mirror and a radiator, so it can reflect sunlight away and send heat out into the sky, so a building can stay cooler without any air conditioning or electricity,” says Du.

To make it, the researchers first produce tiny pellets from common minerals like limestone and gypsum. These are ground to dust and mixed with water before being poured into a silicone mould covered in small holes. Air bubbles passing through the holes create slight depressions in the cement’s surface, where the reflective ettringite crystals can then grow, while an aluminium-rich gel in the set cement lets infrared light pass through the material.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

This process is easily scalable, says Du, and the cement is $5 per tonne cheaper than regular Portland cement because it can be produced at lower temperatures.

Du and her team tested how their cement kept cool on a hot roof at the Purdue University campus, finding that the surface temperature was 5.4°C (9.7°F) lower than the air and 26°C (47°F) lower than the Portland cement.

Dimples in the surface of the cement, viewed with an electron microscope Guo Lu/Southeast University

“It’s a useful material,” says Oscar Brousse at University College London. “You increase the reflective capacity as well as increasing the emissivity, so any energy that is captured or conducted to the material is emitted efficiently back.”

However, measuring only the surface temperature of the material doesn’t tell us how it will perform in the real world, says Brousse, so it should undergo further testing. “It doesn’t mean that because the surface is 5°C lower, that the air temperature will be 5°C lower around it. The effect locally may be greatly limited.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports a new cement formulation that significantly reduces heat absorption in buildings, potentially lowering the need for air conditioning and reducing energy consumption. This innovation has broad environmental benefits by mitigating urban heat and lowering carbon emissions from cooling. The story provides detailed context on the material's composition, testing, and scalability, indicating a meaningful technological and environmental breakthrough.
articles.personality_title: New cement keeps buildings cooler by reflecting and releasing heat
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Buildings made with regular cement can get very hot during sunny days because the cement absorbs and holds heat from the sun. This makes the inside of buildings warmer and can increase the temperature of the air around them.

**What happened** – Researchers at Purdue University created a new type of cement that stays cooler by reflecting sunlight and sending heat away. This cement has tiny crystals called ettringite on its surface which help it reflect infrared light and release heat back into the sky. The team tested this cement on a roof and found it was much cooler than regular cement—about 26°C (47°F) cooler.

**Impact** – This new cement could help buildings stay comfortable without using air conditioning, saving energy and reducing costs. It also costs less to make than regular cement and can be produced in large amounts. Keeping buildings cooler can lower the heat in cities and reduce pollution caused by air conditioning.

**What's next step** – The new cement will need more tests to see how well it works in different places and conditions. Scientists want to understand if it can lower air temperatures around buildings, not just the surface temperature.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new cement that reflects and releases heat could cool buildings naturally, cutting energy use and helping cities stay cooler.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un nouveau ciment qui garde les bâtiments plus frais en réfléchissant et en libérant la chaleur
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les bâtiments en ciment ordinaire deviennent très chauds sous le soleil car le ciment absorbe et retient la chaleur. Cela réchauffe l’intérieur des bâtiments et l’air autour.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’université Purdue ont créé un ciment qui reste plus frais en réfléchissant la lumière du soleil et en renvoyant la chaleur dans le ciel. Ce ciment contient de petits cristaux appelés étrongite qui aident à réfléchir la lumière infrarouge et à libérer la chaleur. Lors d’un test sur un toit, ce ciment était beaucoup plus frais que le ciment normal, environ 26°C de moins.

**Impact** – Ce nouveau ciment pourrait aider à garder les bâtiments confortables sans climatisation, ce qui économise de l’énergie et de l’argent. Il est aussi moins cher à produire et peut être fabriqué en grande quantité. Refroidir les bâtiments peut aussi réduire la chaleur dans les villes et la pollution liée à la climatisation.

**Étape suivante** – Ce ciment devra être testé davantage pour vérifier son efficacité dans différents endroits et conditions. Les chercheurs veulent savoir s’il peut aussi réduire la température de l’air autour des bâtiments.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un nouveau ciment qui réfléchit et libère la chaleur pourrait refroidir naturellement les bâtiments, réduisant la consommation d’énergie et la chaleur urbaine.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo cemento mantiene los edificios más frescos reflejando y liberando calor
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los edificios hechos con cemento normal se calientan mucho en días soleados porque el cemento absorbe y retiene el calor del sol. Esto hace que el interior de los edificios y el aire alrededor se calienten.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad Purdue crearon un cemento que se mantiene más fresco al reflejar la luz del sol y enviar el calor de vuelta al cielo. Este cemento tiene pequeños cristales llamados etringita en su superficie que ayudan a reflejar la luz infrarroja y liberar calor. En una prueba en un techo, este cemento estuvo mucho más fresco que el cemento normal, aproximadamente 26°C menos.

**Impacto** – Este cemento nuevo podría ayudar a mantener los edificios cómodos sin usar aire acondicionado, ahorrando energía y dinero. Además, cuesta menos fabricarlo y se puede producir en grandes cantidades. Mantener los edificios frescos también puede reducir el calor en las ciudades y la contaminación causada por el aire acondicionado.

**Próximo paso** – El cemento necesitará más pruebas para ver qué tan bien funciona en diferentes lugares y condiciones. Los científicos quieren saber si puede bajar también la temperatura del aire alrededor de los edificios.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un nuevo cemento que refleja y libera calor podría enfriar los edificios de forma natural, reduciendo el uso de energía y el calor urbano.
